name: main.chapter.01.topic.01 The Feedback Loop From Hell
summary: Feeling bad about feeling bad creates a downward spiral. Anxiety about anxiety, guilt about guilt—this meta-emotion compounds the original emotion. The key is accepting negative emotions instead of fighting them.

name: main.chapter.01.topic.02 The Subtle Art Of Not Giving a F*ck
summary: Not giving a f*ck doesn't mean being indifferent; it means being comfortable with being different. It's about choosing what you care about with intention. You have a limited number of f*cks to give—spend them wisely.

name: main.chapter.01.topic.03 So Mark, What the F*ck Is the Point?
summary: The point is to learn how to focus and prioritize your thoughts effectively—to care about fewer things, but to care about them more deeply. Stop trying to be positive all the time and accept life's struggles.

name: main.chapter.02.topic.01 The Misadventures of Disappointment Panda
summary: Life is essentially an endless series of problems. The solution to one problem creates a new problem. Happiness comes not from avoiding problems but from solving them.

name: main.chapter.02.topic.02 Happiness Comes from Solving Problems
summary: Problems never stop; they just get upgraded. True happiness occurs when you find the problems you enjoy solving. Don't deny problems or blame others—take responsibility and solve them.

name: main.chapter.02.topic.03 Emotions Are Overrated
summary: Emotions are merely signposts, not destinations. Make values-based decisions, not emotion-based ones. Positive emotions are rewards for solving problems, not solutions themselves.

name: main.chapter.02.topic.04 Choose Your Struggle
summary: What determines success isn't 'What do you want to enjoy?' but 'What pain are you willing to sustain?' The quality of your life is determined by the quality of problems you're willing to solve.

name: main.chapter.03.topic.01 The Tyranny of Exceptionalism
summary: The belief that you're exceptional leads to entitlement and unhappiness. Most of us are pretty average at most things, and that's okay. The obsession with being extraordinary paradoxically makes people feel worse.

name: main.chapter.03.topic.02 Things Fall Apart
summary: When your metrics for success fail, you're forced to reevaluate your values. This painful process is often the catalyst for significant personal growth. Sometimes hitting rock bottom is necessary for change.

name: main.chapter.03.topic.03 If I'm Not Special, What's the Point?
summary: The point is to be exceptional at the things that matter most to you. Not being special doesn't mean being mediocre—it means choosing your battles wisely and excelling in areas aligned with your values.

name: main.chapter.04.topic.01 The Self-Awareness Onion
summary: Layer 1: Understanding your emotions. Layer 2: Understanding why you feel certain emotions. Layer 3: Understanding your personal values and why they matter. Most people never reach layer 3. True self-awareness requires peeling back layers.

name: main.chapter.04.topic.02 Rock Star Problems
summary: Not all suffering is created equal. Choose your struggles wisely. What pain are you willing to sustain? The answer determines what you'll achieve more than talent or passion.

name: main.chapter.04.topic.03 Shitty Values
summary: Pleasure, material success, always being right, and staying positive are poor values because they're not controllable or measurable. They lead to shallow satisfaction and unhappiness.

name: main.chapter.04.topic.04 Defining Good and Bad Values
summary: Good values are reality-based, socially constructive, and controllable (honesty, innovation, vulnerability). Bad values are superstitious, socially destructive, and uncontrollable. Choose values based on what you control.

name: main.chapter.05.topic.01 The Choice
summary: We always have a choice about how we interpret problems and react to them. The only thing we can truly control is how we interpret and respond to events. You are always choosing.

name: main.chapter.05.topic.02 The Responsibility/Fault Fallacy
summary: You're not always at fault for your problems, but you're always responsible for how you respond. Fault is past tense. Responsibility is present tense. Even if a problem isn't your fault, it's your responsibility to deal with it.

name: main.chapter.05.topic.03 Responding to Tragedy
summary: We are responsible for experiences that aren't our fault all the time. This is part of life. How you respond to tragedy defines you more than the tragedy itself.

name: main.chapter.05.topic.04 Genetics and the Hand We're Dealt
summary: You don't choose your genetics, family, or initial circumstances, but you choose how to respond to them. Your hand is dealt; how you play it is your responsibility.

name: main.chapter.05.topic.05 Victimhood Chic
summary: Many people feel entitled either because they believe they're exceptional or because they believe they're victims. Both lead to unhappiness. Real self-worth comes from solving problems.

name: main.chapter.05.topic.06 There Is No 'How'
summary: Stop waiting for the perfect method or the right moment. There is no 'how'—you just choose and do. Action comes first, then learning follows.

name: main.chapter.06.topic.01 But So Am I
summary: Our beliefs are shaped by our experiences and biases, and they're often wrong. Being wrong opens the door to growth. Don't be afraid to be uncertain about your beliefs.

name: main.chapter.06.topic.02 Architects of Our Own Beliefs
summary: We construct our beliefs based on limited information and past experiences. These constructions are often flawed. Growth requires questioning your beliefs and values.

name: main.chapter.06.topic.03 Be Careful What You Believe
summary: Our identity is built on our beliefs and metrics. Changing these beliefs means changing ourselves, which is why it's so difficult and why we resist it.

name: main.chapter.06.topic.04 The Dangers of Pure Certainty
summary: The more certain we are about something, the less likely we are to learn. Uncertainty is the root of all progress and growth. Questions like 'What if I'm wrong?' are essential.

name: main.chapter.06.topic.05 Manson's Law of Avoidance
summary: The more something threatens your identity, the more you will avoid it. People avoid experiences that contradict how they see themselves. To grow, challenge your self-concept.

name: main.chapter.06.topic.06 Kill Yourself
summary: Kill your fantasies about who you should be or what you should achieve. Letting go of these harmful identities is necessary for growth and happiness.

name: main.chapter.06.topic.07 How to Be Less Certain About Yourself
summary: Ask yourself regularly: What if I'm wrong? What would it mean if I were wrong? How would I know if I were wrong? These questions keep you open to growth.

name: main.chapter.07.topic.01 The Failure/Success Paradox
imports: main.chapter.07 Failure Is the Way Forward
summary: Success comes from repeated failure and learning. Fear of failure often causes more failure. Improvement at anything is based on thousands of tiny failures.

name: main.chapter.07.topic.02 Pain Is Part of the Process
imports: main.chapter.07 Failure Is the Way Forward
summary: Pain signals that you're improving. If you're not failing, you're not trying hard enough. Embrace the struggle as evidence of progress, not as a reason to quit.

name: main.chapter.07.topic.03 The 'Do Something' Principle
imports: main.chapter.07 Failure Is the Way Forward
summary: Action → Inspiration → Motivation → More action. Don't wait for motivation—just do something. Even if it's the wrong action, it provides information. Motion creates emotion.

name: main.chapter.08.topic.01 Rejection Makes Your Life Better
imports: main.chapter.08 The Importance of Saying No
summary: For any change to happen, something must be rejected. Freedom requires rejection. To truly value something, you must reject alternatives. Saying 'no' gives your 'yes' more meaning.

name: main.chapter.08.topic.02 Boundaries
imports: main.chapter.08 The Importance of Saying No
summary: Healthy relationships require boundaries. Without boundaries, relationships become toxic. Setting boundaries means being willing to say no and accepting others saying no to you.

name: main.chapter.08.topic.03 How to Build Trust
imports: main.chapter.08 The Importance of Saying No
summary: Trust is built through conflict resolution, not conflict avoidance. Healthy relationships embrace conflict as necessary for growth. The willingness to say and hear 'no' builds trust.

name: main.chapter.08.topic.04 Freedom Through Commitment
imports: main.chapter.08 The Importance of Saying No
summary: True freedom comes from commitment and rejection of alternatives. The paradox of choice: more options lead to less satisfaction. Commitment gives depth and meaning by narrowing options.

name: main.chapter.09.topic.01 Something Beyond Ourselves
summary: Your life's meaning isn't determined by your lasting impact but by the values you live by while you're here. Most legacies are forgotten within generations—and that's okay.

name: main.chapter.09.topic.02 The Sunny Side of Death
summary: Death is the only certainty. Confronting mortality clarifies what matters. When we avoid thinking about death, we make poor decisions. Death is the light by which all of life's meaning is measured.

name: main.chapter.01 Don't Try
summary: The pursuit of positive experience is itself a negative experience, while accepting negative experience is a positive experience. Stop trying so hard to be happy and accept the struggle. The desire for more positive experiences is paradoxically a negative experience.

name: main.chapter.02 Happiness Is a Problem
summary: Problems never stop; they just get upgraded. Happiness comes from solving problems, not avoiding them. Life is essentially an endless series of problems, and the solution to one problem creates a new problem. This is a feature, not a bug.

name: main.chapter.03 You Are Not Special
summary: The belief that you're exceptional leads to entitlement and unhappiness. Most of us are pretty average at most things, and that's okay. The obsession with being extraordinary paradoxically makes people feel worse about themselves.

name: main.chapter.04 The Value of Suffering
summary: Not all suffering is created equal. What determines your success isn't 'What do you want to enjoy?' but 'What pain do you want to sustain?' Choose your struggle. The quality of your life is determined by the quality of the problems you're willing to solve.

name: main.chapter.05 You Are Always Choosing
summary: We are responsible for experiences that aren't our fault all the time. This is part of life. We always have a choice about how we interpret problems and react to them. The only thing we can truly control is how we interpret and respond to events.

name: main.chapter.06 You're Wrong About Everything
summary: Growth requires questioning your beliefs and values. Our beliefs are shaped by our experiences and biases, and they're often wrong. Being wrong opens the door to growth. Don't be afraid to be uncertain about your beliefs.

name: main.chapter.07 Failure Is the Way Forward
summary: Success comes from repeated failure and learning. Fear of failure often causes more failure. Improvement at anything is based on thousands of tiny failures. Pain is part of the process and signals that you're improving.

name: main.chapter.08 The Importance of Saying No
summary: Freedom requires rejection. To truly value something, you must reject alternatives. Commitment gives you freedom by narrowing down your options. For any change to happen, something must be rejected.

name: main.chapter.09 ...And Then You Die
summary: Death is the only certainty. Confronting mortality clarifies what matters. When we avoid thinking about death, we unconsciously make decisions based on avoiding it. Death is the light by which the shadow of all of life's meaning is measured.

name: main.section_name.01 Core Philosophy
summary: The foundation: Not giving a f*ck doesn't mean being indifferent; it means being comfortable with being different and choosing what matters. Chapters 1-3 establish the philosophical groundwork.

name: main.section_name.02 Choosing Your Values
summary: Values determine how we measure success. Choose values you can control that are reality-based and socially constructive. Chapters 4-6 teach how to choose better values.

name: main.section_name.03 Taking Action
summary: Action precedes motivation. Failure is the path forward. Commitment requires rejection. Chapters 7-9 show how to take action on your values and live with death in mind.
